Thanks,
I agree with the idea about "if you are doing it properly you don't=

need this"...
I'm trying to migrate a dev/QA team over to the "right" way =
and I
suppose
the QA team are scared about loosing visibility into the test=
s (that are
written by the developers).

We will have nightly builds and th=
ey will run the tests and I suppose
they want to be able to get some visibi=
lity into the fixing of these
problems. There is a fair argument that they =
don't need to know, that
is the beauty...
Thanks for the long response!
Ala=
n.

-----Original Message-----
From: Andrew Clarke [mailto:andrew.clarke@cm=
gplc.com]
Sent: 19 November 2001 14:12
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Subject:=
 RE: [junit] Integration between JUnit and bug tracker?


Forgive me, but i=
sn't this rather contrary to the spirit of JUnit and
its
TestInfected/XP ap=
proach?  Kent says we're supposed to cycle through the
testing and coding s=
tages a few times until our code has no bugs.  So
what
is there to track?  =
same goes for integration: providing we're
developing in
small enough chunk=
s, of course.

Or look at it another way: our failed tests are their own bu=
g
trackingdevice.

Automatically populating a bug track database from faile=
d tests would
only
make sense when the people running the tests aren't the =
same people who
are
developing the code, for instance users in UAT or a "bl=
ack box" testing
cell.  I don't think JUnit is sufficiently abstract for th=
e former but I
can
see that the latter could be writing their own JUnit sui=
tes (if they
know
Java).  In which case your question is simply a variant o=
n the "How do I
log
output from JUnit?" question, only instead of writing t=
o a logfile you
want
to insert the results into an error tracking database.=
  How difficult
that
is depends on the database in question: if it's someth=
ing proprietary
like
Merant Tracker I imagine there'll be a few more proble=
ms than if (like
us)
you're using a homebrew system based on tables sitting=
 in your
development
Oracle DB.  The Bugzilla FAQ does say we write to the =
database using the
Mozilla XML API so it would be possible to do, but I thi=
nk you'll be
lucky
to find anyone who's actually done it :P  

rgds, APC
